title-group.article-title: Contribution of Clinical Trial Event Data by Data Source
title-group.subtitle: A Prespecified Analysis of the ADAPTABLE Randomized Clinical Trial
title-group.alt-title: Contribution of Clinical Trial Event Data by Data Source
Contribution of Clinical Trial Event Data by Data Source

article-meta.aff: 1Duke Clinical Research Institute, Durham, North Carolina
3John Ochsner Heart and Vascular Institute, University of Queensland–Ochsner Clinical School, New Orleans, Louisiana

author-notes.title: Article Information
author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Jennifer A. Rymer, MD, MBA, MHS, Duke Clinical Research Institute, 300 W Morgan St, Durham, NC 27701 (jennifer.rymer@duke.edu).
author-notes.p: Author Contributions: Dr Rymer had full access to all of the data in the study and takes responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.
Concept and design: Rymer, Mulder, Muñoz, Kripalani, Benziger, Knowlton, Curtis, Roe, Rothman, Harrington, Hernandez, Jones.

Acquisition, analysis, or interpretation of data: Rymer, Mulder, Wruck, Muñoz, Effron, Gupta, Handberg, Jain, Girotra, Whittle, Hess, Benziger, Knowlton, Hammill, Rothman, Harrington, Hernandez, Jones.
Drafting of the manuscript: Rymer, Benziger, Knowlton.
Critical review of the manuscript for important intellectual content: All authors.
Statistical analysis: Rymer, Mulder, Wruck, Knowlton, Hammill, Jones.
Administrative, technical, or material support: Rymer, Girotra, Whittle, Hess, Hammill, Harrington, Hernandez.
Supervision: Rymer, Wruck, Muñoz, Kripalani, Benziger, Knowlton, Roe, Rothman, Harrington, Jones.

Conflict of Interest Disclosures: Dr Rymer reported grants from Novo Nordisk, advisory board fees from Chiesi, and consulting fees from Abbott outside the submitted work. Dr Kripalani reported grants from Esperion and personal fees from Gilead Sciences outside the submitted work. Dr Effron reported having a pension and stock from Eli Lilly outside the submitted work. Dr Jain reported research funding from Medtronic and Boston Scientific outside the submitted work. Dr Girotra reported grants from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (R01HL160734 and R01HL166305) outside the submitted work. Dr Hess reported serving on a data and safety monitoring board (DSMB) for Astellas Pharmaceuticals outside the submitted work. Dr Benziger reported serving on a trial steering committee for Novartis outside the submitted work. Dr Knowlton reported grants from the National Institutes of Health during the conduct of the study. Dr Roe reported being an employee of AstraZeneca and receiving stock grants as part of their employment. Dr Harrington reported trial leadership and/or trial oversight funding from Janssen, CSL, Edwards, and Merck; consulting, advisory, and/or DSMB fees from Atropis, Bitterroot Bio, Bristol Myers Squibb, BridgeBio, Chiesi, Element Science, and Foresight; educational program fees from WebMD; and serving on the board of directors for Cytokinetics outside the submitted work. Dr Hernandez reported grants from AstraZeneca, Amgen, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bayer, Merck, and Novartis outside the submitted work. No other disclosures were reported.
Funding/Support: This work was supported through an award from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (ASP-1502-27029).

Role of the Funder/Sponsor: The funder had no role in the design and conduct of the study; collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of the data; preparation, review, or approval of the manuscript; and decision to submit the manuscript for publication.

abstract.p: This analysis of a randomized clinical trial examines the clinical event data to determine which source of data (eg, electronic health records, claims, participant reports) made the greatest relative contribution to the primary end point rates.

sec.title: Question
sec.p: Which source of data provides the greatest relative contribution for clinical end-point examination in pragmatic randomized clinical trials?

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: In this prespecified analysis of a randomized clinical trial, most events (92%-100%) were identified in the electronic health record (EHR) or in claims data. Participant-reported data contributed less than 10% of events not otherwise available from claims or EHR data.

sec.title: Meaning
sec.p: In a large pragmatic randomized clinical trial, claims and EHR data provided the most clinical end-point data when compared with participant-reported events.

sec.title: Importance
sec.p: Pragmatic randomized clinical trials (RCTs) often use multiple data sources to examine clinical events, but the relative contribution of data sources to clinical end-point rates is understudied.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To assess the contribution of data sources (electronic health records [EHRs], public/private insurance claims, and/or participant-reported data) to clinical end points among ADAPTABLE participants who had available data.

sec.title: Design, Setting, and Participants
sec.p: The ADAPTABLE study was an open-label, pragmatic RCT from April 2016 through June 2019 conducted in research networks within clinical practice. Participants had existing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and available data to analyze. The characteristics of patients by combinations of data source availability were compared to examine the contribution of each of the data sources to end-point ascertainment. Data for this prespecified analysis were examined from January 2022 to June 2023.

sec.title: Exposures
sec.p: Randomized exposure to 81 mg or 325 mg of aspirin daily.

sec.title: Main Outcomes and Measures
sec.p: Number of events for the primary end point (composite of death, hospitalization for myocardial infarction, and hospitalization for stroke) that were contributed by EHR or claims data and then number of events contributed by each additional data source.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of 15 006 participants randomized with at least 1 other source of data available beyond participant-reported data, there were 8756 (58.3%) with participant-reported and EHR data; 4291 (28.6%) with participant-reported, EHR, and claims data; 1412 (9.4%) with EHR-only data; 262 (1.7%) with participant-reported and claims data; 202 (1.3%) with EHR and claims data; and 83 (0.6%) with claims-only data. Participants with EHR-only data were younger (median age, 63.7 years; IQR, 55.8-71.4) compared with the other groups (range, 65.6-71.9 years). Among participants with both EHR and claims data, with or without participant-reported data (n = 4493), for each outcome, most events (92%-100%) were identified in the EHR or in claims data. For all clinical end points, participant-reported data contributed less than 10% of events not otherwise available from claims or EHR data.

sec.title: Conclusions and Relevance
sec.p: In this analysis of a pragmatic RCT, claims and EHR data provided the most clinical end-point data when compared with participant-reported events. These findings provide a framework for collecting end points in pragmatic clinical trials. Further work is needed to understand the data source combinations that most effectively provide clinical end-point data in RCTs.
